pada.s: O sun glory, o sun of [re]birth, you have surpassed all suns with your light, [1a] o powerful Viṣṇu, ... [1b] kauna-peñyai , kauṃ cmelṣu ; po kauñäkteṃ , ṣeṣṣirku ; läkUtsowñaisa :
maiyyā preñcai , vikṣnu ///

the ... of the elephants you have surpassed with [your] course, and with [your] voice all clouds: [1c]
/// (oṅko)lmaṃts , yämaisa ; weśeññaisa , tärkärwa ; po ṣārkatai :
..., to these two friends you have kept in countless [re]births; [2a] mñe ; tai wāṣmone , eṅsā(t)ai ; (snai) (k)eś cmela :

you have made yourself firm (in order to bear) ... the sorrows of the saṃsāra; [2b] prakkreṃ ṣäñ-āñm , klyautkatai ; saṃsār(ṣṣana) , (lä)klenta ; kä
(ltsi) ///
with (unremitting energy) you set out, (ready on the arhat road); [2c] , (warkṣä)ltsa ; mäst= ārwāre :
your deep compassion has surpassed even love like loving mothers to [their] sons. [2d] täṅwä(ssonta) , (mā)tarñ ramt ; täṅw sÄsuwane , ṣārkate-c ; ka(ruṃ) (au)rtstse :

In the terrible (wilds they ate the flesh of [their own] son, confused because of hunger): [3a] empe
(le) ///
they forgot [their] love to [their] son täṅw märsāre , sÄsuwerṣe ;
[and] ... (saved) their own dear life; [3b] , (pa)ṣṣānte ; lareṃ ṣäñ śaul :

in the (shape) of an elephant (you threw yourself) from a mountain (as food for [those] hungry) [3c] ... oṅkol(m)a(ññai) , (särwe)śne ; ṣlemeṃ ṣä
(ñ-āñm) ,
[Your] (wisdom) (about the ...) of the saṃsāra made you understand everything, little (and big) [4a] saṃsārantse , ; (aiśämñe) (ci) , po śārsa ; lykä(śke) (trekte)

... your ... has compelled you to ... here; [4b]
/// (ṣā)rtate-c ; tnek sā

... (you have given up for) our (sake)
lñeṣṣe ; wesäñ (ṣärm)ts(a) , (rintsatai) ;
and you have endured [it] (here): [4c] (tnek) (ke)lästā :

the beings (?) ... with [your] mind. [4d] o
/// p(a)lskosa :
The thought of compassion never let you feel happy (like) with divine (pleasures); [5a] ñäkcya(na) (ramt) , (skwänma)n(e) ; skwantsi nta kca , carkā-c mā ; karuṃ pal(sko)
«for this ... world (is) entrusted to me; /// kṣ·· , śaiṣṣe se ; ñi wa senik , (wärpau) (ste) ;
me it has taken as [its] refuge» [5c] ñiś wast= eṅku :

[but] it gave up divine happiness and ... detestable animal state ... [5d] rīnäṣṣiträ säkw ña(kcye) lwāñai śconai
///
(When you were a lion), a she-monkey entrusted her two offspring to you; [6a] ; ṣeyyiśkane , mokauśka ; se(nik) ·ly·y·-c :
a vulture carried them off; sayusā ceṃ cālate
you saw that tu lyakāsta
and out of compassion your mind shocked; [6b] ka(r)u(ṃ)ts(a) naitta-c päls(k)o :

([and] with the blood from your flanks you bought) [back] their (lives) and did not let off – [6c]
/// (tai)ynesiñ mā ṣp maukāsta :
thus your compassionate mind was hidden in animal appearance, o so tender one! [6d] karuṃ palsko te-yknesā lwāññe rupne tukau ṣai-c tot lalaṃ(ṣka)

(When you were a turtle), you gave [your] body away (to the merchants to be stripped), [7a] ///
/// kektseñ wsāstā :
[and] with your body skinned you let them cross over the wide river by your love: [7b] papāsausai kektsentsa śetkasta ceṃ cäk= aurce śār maiytartsa :
(you have seen) hungry (animals) (and put yourself [a whole] kalpa to damage in order to feed them); [7c keścyeṃ l(wāsa) ,

they cut off your (flesh) ///
/// , latkānte-c ;
– o, pitying help and stay, you endured all! [7d] āñmālaṣka , saim-wasta ; po kelasta :
You have seen the sorrows through hunger and illness (of the people) ... [8a] kest tekisa , läkle(nta) ;
as out of compassion you set out with calm in the eight ... [8c] ... (the heart [was] hit). [8d] (A woman) ... [9a] stiyais= oktne , karuntsa ; mäkte mästā , ///

line.tr: I will not arise without having achieved the Buddha [worth]! (148, 151)

comments.comment: For detailed philological comments, see (passim). Below, only corrections to the article are noted.
tärnesa: 'with the top of my head', not 'with my skull'.
eṅsā(t)ai: this reading, instead of eṅsā(t)e, I owe to Ronald I. Kim (Poznań), p.c.
: in a3, smā(ṃ) is 'test', not 'repetition', according to .
lwāñai śconai: 'detestable animal state', not 'animal hatred' ().

line.tr: In the year nine, in the 3rd month, on the 17th day, under the rule of the Great Kuchean King Salare*. At this moment, (being present at ...?),
a Prince Niyire*'s mañiye called Massone (and) his brother called [P]urnāśä, these two (are namely) us. Here (are) [his(?)] saṃgha's
mañiye called Puṣpakerti (and) his wife called Netla. • (Here) is the son of those two called Eśkulke.
[This] Eśkulke, we two bought from (his) father (and) mother in a bad, famine period. The Moko
monk agreed. • [Here] (and) now, this Eśkulke is not happy near by us (i.e. by our side). For this reason, we sell this
Eśkulke. (Here) are a [monk] of Yurpāṣka (with the title) Abhidharmike called Buddhavräddhi,
an Araññe called Dharmaśarme, an Araññe called Aryavräddhi, (and) their brother called Samyosä.
We sell him to them: 105000 Kuchean coins in cash(?). Without yakau, without (any)thing left to be paid. ...
shall be (his/its) [own](?). Forever in the future, he should not be claimed by anyone else nor should be enquired about (by anyone else). [Here] (are): Dharmattrāte the Saṅka-
-dhare • Dharmaruci the Araññe • Dharmasene the Araññe • Dharmarakṣite the Araññe •
Buddhabhadre the Agamadhare (and) the Praskāre • Dharmanāre the Agamadhare (and) the Praskāre • Nokarti, the brother of the Ṣletaś • Arśol
the Orśa • Arcu[t]a the King's kalyä • Eñcike, the son of the Oko_u* of Preyole* • Arosä the King's kārṣṣe •
At this moment, ... [Ā]ryakame (or: [A]ryakame) ... Koramakke. The kañe of himself/oneself/itself ... of Massone ...

comments.comment: prokṣi could be similar to plaṅṣi 'selling', ākṣi 'announcing' (). However, it is unclear which verb this form could be derived from. Alternatively, it could be a loan from Sanskrit prokṣ- 'to sprinkle'.
argues that *pār could be a unit of measurement related to Sogdian p'r and Khotanese pāra-.

Ogihara's reading c[ai]tkiṃ is probably incorrect. The 'ca' is too low to be an independent akṣara, and the part above it doesn't look like an ai-diacritic. I think 'ñc·' is the most likely reading here.

translation.line: ... they ask you about the thing for the kapyār...

comments.comment: This reading, instead of salapaṣ (), follows (Sergey Malyshev and Ilya Itkin, p.c.).

Literally, 'on the 29': (wiki)-ñupyaṃ is the loc. of wiki-ñupi '29', denoting the date of the order (cf. also THT 1519 3). This restoration follows a suggestion of Ilya Itkin (p.c.). An alternative restoration would be (śäk)-ñupyaṃ, in which case there was a virāma after (śäk), i.e. (śak\)-ñupya[ṃ].
Edition and translation based on with corrections by Ilya Itkin (p.c.).

line.tr: The people of Yurpāṣka have given, from Na[nnañ]ñ(e) (of) Ylāpar,
(sth.) of the 10th year ... to be given in ...
In the 10th year, in the 5th month, on the 7th day. The Yurpaṣgaṣṣi (people) have given the coins
by half (from) *Nanaṃkañeme in Lapar, the 10th-year honami, by giving daṃda (as) the price:
1000. Ośaṃ Ṣanmire (and?) Ku[bh]enare (and?) Dinasme have received (them).

line.tr: On water a spell is to be cast. The face is to be washed. She
Sanskrit Thereby one who is evil-minded becomes friendly.

comments.comment: The short text shows late/colloquial forms as well as wrong orthography:

The Tocharian text has been written on the blank space after a Sanskrit donor text (ed. in as no. SHT 146) by a different hand with a brush; the script is very clumsy. The leaf comes from the only complete Sanskrit pustaka book unearthed from Qizil, see ; and the wooden covers and belong to the same pustaka.
For the use of the cross-barred square sign to render ‹mä›, see .
In contrast to , opätsa rather seems to be a complete form; connects it with TA 'jealousy' and suggests a privative adjective 'not jealous'.

Skt. prasunna- stands for correct Skt. prasanna- ‘clear, friendly’, and °manasa for genitival °manasaḥ, visarga being usually omitted in texts from Eastern Turkestan; note also the use of the genitive instead of the expected dative.
mäsketra with 3.sg. ending -ra but in addition the kind of hypercorrect spelling with d in mäskedra.

mamanto-pälsko shows late diphthongization; the form seems to be a bahuvrihi compound consisting of the PPt mamāntau ‘being evil’ and of palsko ‘mind, spirit’. Note further that the Sanskrit is also corrupt, which is often the case in this pustaka (cf. ), esp. with respect to wrong vowels.
Four fragments from one single leaf; lines 1-5 contain Mahāparinirvāṇasūtra in Sanskrit (ed. . (no. 211) and 386-388; line 6 contains Sanskrit/TB Udv. 1.18. Recto side is blank.

line.tr: [TA] ... like immortals. [SKT] But [who] know the good law ...
[TA] though having eyes he does not see [them].
[SKT] ... does not distinguish. [TA] Not having heard (= studied) ...
[SKT] ... like one ... can see, [TA] (Like) one having eyes ...
[TA] ... having heard (= studied) (one can distinguish) evil ...
[TA] ... because of his having moral behaviour they praise him. [SKT] Him ...

comments.comment: A fragment that preserves practically the whole string hole space and the full height, but no margins.

/// – mäṣṣ oki: translates Skt. amarā iva 'like immortals' Uv.22.2b. A form of oṅkraci 'immortal' is excluded; it is certainly the nom. pl.m. ending of an adj. in -um, perhaps mā wlaluneyum 'not dying'?
epukk ats: the emphatic particles render su- in Skt. succhannaṃ of Uv.22.3a.

The Skt. text of Uv.22.3d is cakṣuṣmāṃ hi na paśyati. Although cakṣuṣmāṃ 'having eyes' is restored in Bernhard's , it is abundantly secured, e.g. by the Gāndhārī Dharmapada 251d, cakhkṣuma () and Tib. 22.3d mig ldan. The TA correspondence is certainly an adj. ending in -um, i.e. aśnum.
Uv.22.7d-8a: nāsya saṃpadyate śrutam // 7 alpaśruto ’pi ced bhavati
Uv.22.8c-d: śilatas taṃ praśaṃsanti tasya saṃpadyate śrutam

pāpṣ[u]ney[u]ṣ a cross above the line between the akṣaras y[u] and ṣ(·)[a] marks an addition below, which is itself lost. Probably we have to read pāpṣuneyu(mä)ṣ as a translation of śilatas and restore the addition as _m_a.

(tä)ṣn(e) wkäṃnyo lit. 'in this way' renders Skt. tathā. Here it is to be understood as 'and likewise'.
Pace K.T. Schmidt apud with fn. 5 one has to read obl.pl. paṃñäkteṃ even though one would, of course, expect a nominative.

The recto side contains a Sanskrit Prātimokṣa text, the verso side contains two lines in TB on top of the leaf, which is written by a different hand than the recto side in a clumsy, uneven ductus; on the bottom of the otherwise blank side one finds another TB clause written again by a different hand in normal book-style ductus.
Although this Sanskrit fragment has received a THT number, it is not bilingual and does not contain Tocharian.

comments.comment: This document is mostly in Sanskrit. However, on the recto, there are what appears to be glosses interspersed between the lines. a3i uses a Fremdzeichen, so we might be dealing with Tocharian. However, I could not identify any word.

provenance.expeditionCode: T III M 132, T III M 143, T III M 145

comments.comment: The interpretation of this gloss is uncertain: the reading is not secured and the Sanskrit text is incomplete. If the gloss is read correctly, k(a)vāre may stand for kāpāre 'morsels, bite-size pieces' (). Since kāpār is borrowed from (a Middle Indian form corresponding to) Skt. kavaḍa (see Carling, l.c.), it is understandable that the word was spelled differently. Both the short a and the v are closer to the Skt. form. The semantic connection may be understood as 'crushed' = 'small pieces'. Even if Waldschmidt's cautious restoration to (na)[ṭa]kuṭṭā 'wie Spaßmacher' ['like jesters'] (in ) is correct, the TA gloss could be an “incorrect” too literal rendering of only the last part of the word.

Pace (accepted by a), who sees a connection with kātk- 'be glad', kātkāśi does not gloss the following word hāsyaprekṣy 'makes laugh'. Apart from the fact that the gloss is actually found under gṛhiṇo, kātkāśi could not possibly be a form of kātk-: there is no agent suffix -śi v.s., and probably no stem of a causative of this structure would have a long ā in the second syllable, not even the subjunctive stem (, ). TA kātkāśi, for kātkāśśi, is probably in th eplural because this word has become a plurale tantum: no singular forms are attested at all and the nom.sg. kātak* () is set up on the basis of plural forms.

glosses Skt. gṛhiṇo (gen.sg.) 'householder'. To the right of kātkāśi a further gloss hā is found, which clarifies that the first akṣara of hāsyaprekṣy is to be read hā: this akṣara is difficult to read and seems to have been corrected from p.

provenance.expeditionCode: T III M 132, T III M 143, T III M 145

comments.comment: reads klāwatra , which cannot be correct. On top of the akṣara ṣ[t]rä a horizontal line is found that is apparently not to be taken as an anusvāra; a suffixed klāwaṣ[t]r-äṃ would not be expected on the basis of the Sanskrit text anyhow. klāwaṣ[t]rä probably stands for klāwäṣträ* (with wa for wä), the 3sg.prs. of the otherwise unattested caus. klāw-, caus., 'call; recite'. Apparently, the 3sg. mistakenly glosses the 3pl. of the Sanskrit text.

This gloss is difficult to interpret for a number of reasons. First of all, śarkä seems to be only the beginning of a word, since no TA word ends in -ä and a corrected reading śark does not yield any known form. On the assumption that it is to be completed as a finite verbal form, the most likely verb from a grammatical point of view is kärk- 'bind'. for which an s-preterite is attested. This would result in a 3sg.pt. śarkä〈s〉 'bound'. However, this meaning does not fit the context at all. A second verb fits the context much better: tsärk- 'torment'. For this verb, the meaning 'burn' is attested in TB, and it fits the story inasfar as ultimately king Māghandika pays back his daughter, who has made it possible that he has become king, by burning her rival and her rival's 500 harem women (). This interpretation can, however, only be put forward with caution, since the TA verb tsärk- is only attested with a vn tsärślune 'torment', which may well have to be explained as an isolated remnant of a verb that has otherwise disappeared from the language. Nevertheless, this verb very probably did form an s- preterite originally (). A further assumption that is needed is that the Tocharian glossator misunderstood the Sanskrit construction and glossed pratikṛtaṃ as if it were an isolated participle, i.e. 'paid back' (as it is translated above). In fact, it is part of a compound tense: kiṃ mayā tasyāḥ kṛtaṃ vā syāt pratikṛtaṃ vā 'Was könnte von mir für sie getan oder in Vergeltung getan werden?' ['What could be done by me for her, or done to pay back?'] (Waldschmidt, l.c.).
possibly explains Skt. pratikṛtaṃ vā 'or paid back' (on the actual meaning in the context, see below).

This gloss, which might also have [n]u as its first akṣara, is unclear. At the right edge of the same line. a further gloss t· /// is found, glossing dvigu(ṇaṃ) 'double' or the following word, which is lost. Excluded are in any case TA wäṣt 'double' and treyo 'thrice'.
glosses Skt. sthāpitāḥ 'established' (cf. , '... Die dort als Verwalter eingesetzt waren' ['... who were instated as stewards there']).

provenance.expeditionCode: T III M 153, T III M 169

recto.line: a ne wa ṣta[ṃ] tu sa kkā¯ ¯K

transcription.prose:
ane waṣtaṃtu sakkāk
ets yisli
pakärkas

comments.comment: Admittedly, ane 'inside, into' is normally not used as a preposition, but only as a postposition or an adverb, usually following a noun (). Nevertheless, taking it here as 'into' fits the context: the women are filling all possible storage place with (inflammable) substances.
Even though the form of the word is a little surprising, sakkāk clearly stands for TA skāk* 'balcony' ().
ane waṣtaṃtu glosses Skt. śayanā 'Lagerstätten' ['storage facilities'] (); sakkāk glosses Skt. karṇaprāsādāḥ (nom.pl.) 'Ausbau; Erker (?)' ['extension; gazebo (?)'] (; , 'Ausbauten' ['extensions']).
ets glosses Skt. irṣyāko (for īrṣyako) 'jealous' (cf. , 'eifersüchtig'); yisli glosses Skt. matsarī 'envious, jealous' (cf. , 'neidisch').
The spelling of pakärkas is remarkable: it must stand for pkärkäs* (Ilya Itkin, p.c.; not päkärkäs* as per , ).
glosses Skt. badhnata (2pl.ipv.; for badhnīta, see ) 'bind!'.

transcription.prose:
ridāt yräcai
riyac pk«ant»
arṣānt-äṃ
ritwasi wāsko

comments.comment: Obviously, ridāt stands for ritāt, 3sg.pt. of räytā- 'seek'. The other gloss, yräcai, is unclear. In TA, we would expect kucā or kucyo, which we definitely do not have here. Also a misspelling for e.g. TB mäkcai 'which?' seems excluded.

ridāt glosses Skt. parimargati (3sg.prs. in past context; for parimārgati, see ) 'seeks about, strives for' (cf. , 'forschte nach' ['inquired']). yräcai glosses Skt. kena (instr.sg., here interrogative) 'by whom?' (cf. ).

pka is probably to be completed (against the manuscript) as pk〈änt〉 'without', but it should be noted that this postposition normally takes the ablative, i.e. we would expect riyäṣ pkänt (in order to solve this problem, Georges-Jean Pinault suggests (p.c.) to consider reading e.g. ri yac\ pka 'you make the town...', which, as, notes, does not seem to be better). Instead of the all.sg. riyac\ one might also read an all.pl. risac\ , though that is clearly less likely. The horizontal stroke over the akṣara pka does not look like an anusvāra and might instead be a mark that the word is abbreviated. However, this stroke is very similar to the one over TA a4 klāwaṣ[t]rä, which does not sem to mark an abbreviation.

glosses Skt. nirviṣayaṃ 'having no place to live, banned'; cf. , who reads the rest of the line as te [v]yā(diśāmi ?) ///, cf. also , noting, “[d]ie erkennbaren Reste der ersten Silbe legen die Lesung [d]yā nahe, womit ich nicht recht etwas anzufangen weiß” [“The recognizable remnants of the first syllable suggest to read [d]yā, which I do not really know what to do with”.] , would read nec[ch]ā ///, i.e. perhaps necchā(mī).

The reading of the anusvāra is uncertain since it has the same shape as the horizontal stroke over TA a4 klāwaṣ[t]rä and above a4 pka, where it is probably not to be taken as an anusvāra; here at least it makes sense in the context. The imperfect of ar- 'cause' was so far not attested (cf. ), but is fully regular. Perhaps the gloss indicates that grāhaya- is to be taken as a real causative, i.e. 'made him take' (the meaning is listed as unclear in ). In any case, there is no lexical link between Skt. grah- 'take' and TA ar-.
glosses Skt. grāhayaṃti (3pl.prs., here in past context) 'they took (him by his pride)'? (cf. , '(bei seinem Stolz) packten sie (ihn)').

ritwasi: The infinitive ending -si for regular -tsi is common. The gloss [yapra] above the line is unclear. Perhaps pra is to be taken together with yuktaṃ below (the exceptionally low positioning of the gloss suggests appurtenance to the line below rather than above) to read prayuktaṃ. The preceding [ya] remains unclear. An unclear /// ·i glosses pariveṣṭuṃ at the beginning of the same line. This ·i can hardly be restored to an infinitive, since the consonant underneath seems not to be s.

wāsko is a new word, probably 'movable, quick', derived from wāskā- 'move' following the pattern of nawo 'roaring' from näw- 'roar' and tālo 'miserable' from täl 'lift up, carry'. Thus, in spite of the fact thatwāsko is clearly placed under °daṇḍaḥ, it certainly refers to āśu°.

ritwasi glosses Skt. °yuktaṃ 'fastened', here 'provided with'; cf. , whose reading cakrayuktaṃ (in l.c.) or ca[k[(r)ayuktaṃ in transliteration in is to be preferred over ca[k](r)a[ṃ] yuktaṃ in . The apparent anusvāra is part of a gloss.
wāsko glosses Skt. āśudaṇḍaḥ 'with a quick stick' (cf. ).

comments.comment: /// te: either 2.8d te or 2.9b namo'rhate. to might be to[_s](_a_ṣ\) 'these', but a precise parallel in the Skt. text is not found.
: restoration uncertain. wmār 'jewel' as the translation of Skt. ratna, frequent in these strophes, is excluded.
either 2.11a–b rūparatnātmabhāvāya cittaratnāntarātmane or 2.13a–b namas te rūparatnāya cittara(tnā)ya te nama(ḥ) (in the latter case, it would provide the tnā restored by ).
wināsam: probably (ci) wināsam 'I honour you' v.s., as a translation of e.g. 2.11d, 2.12d, 2.13b, 2.13d te namaḥ.
The language of this fragment was identified by Klause Wille and Dieter Maue (p.c.). Dieter Maue also read es·i 'to give'.
(wa)ṣtaṃ: the akṣara trace before ṣtaṃ seem compatible with w, but not with for instance pra (cf. praṣtaṃ 'at the time').
es(s)i: under the s, a small trace compatible with a second s can be discerned.
